Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Resolution Mass Spectrometer (HRMS) for Interdisciplinary Research and Teaching in the Southeast Region of Georgia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Georgia Southern University (GSU) is acquiring a high-resolution, high-pressure, liquid chromatograph, quadrupole, time-of-flight mass spectrometer (HR-HPLC-Q-TOF-MS) to support Professor Nathaniel Shank and colleagues Mitch Weiland, Shainaz Landge, Gary Guillet and Kai Shen from Savannah State University (SSU). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and the ions' masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. In the time-of-flight (TOF) method of mass spectrometry, the mass-to-charge ratio of an ion is determined by the way ions are accelerated by an electric field of known strength. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. It also provides training opportunities to many undergraduate students at these institution and serves as a resource for students to get hands-on exposure to advanced instrumentation resulting in a higher quality of education.

The award of the mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The instrument will be used for the development of peptide nucleic acid probes and the profiling Sigma-1 receptor metabolites which regulates calcium signaling in chaperone proteins. The instrumentation is used for characterizing air-sensitive transition metal complexes and developing ruthenium catalysts. In addition, it is used to identify oligonucleotide-protein conjugates. The mass spectrometer is utilized to analyze triazole based chemosensors and logic gates, as well as interface degradation. Finally, it is also utilized to characterize protein mimics and to identify chalcone analogues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Georgia Southern University Research and Service Foundation, Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEORGIA SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY RESEARCH & SERVICE FOUNDATION INC

Performance_Institution.Name: Georgia Southern University Research and Service Foundation, Inc

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant enabled Georgia Southern University (GaSU) to procure a high-resolution mass spectrometer (HRMS, Shimadzu LCMS 9030) that supports the university as well as local, state, and national collaborations. Prior to the acquisition of this instrument, there were no HRMS capabilities available for use within the region, making the purchase critical to enabling current and inspiring future research. The instrument is essential for confirming the elemental composition of small and large molecules and was adapted to analyze extremely air-sensitive compounds. Internal and external researchers were trained on the instrument and additional collaborators submitted samples for analysis.

The instrument has supported research involving peptide nucleic acid monomers and oligomers, symmetrical and unsymmetrical cyanine dyes, DNA/RNA derivatives, air-sensitive transition metal complexes, perfluoroalkanes detection, water contaminants, diarylpentanones, chromenoquinoxalines, bis(pyrazolyl)phenylene(bisamides), benzoimidazoles, and chromanones. These projects have included the work of faculty within the department as well as collaborations with external academic units (South University, University of Saint Joseph, St. Joseph’s University, and the City College of New York). Additionally, the instrument has enabled partnering with local industry (SNF Holding Company) and organizations (Ogeechee Riverkeepers), which has furthered the opportunities for all stakeholders within the immediate community.

In addition to scholarly use, the instrument has been incorporated into the organic and bioinstrumental courses offered at Georgia Southern University (Armstrong Campus). This has resulted in additional use of the instrument as a teaching resource and allowed non-research students in these courses to obtain hands-on experience with state-of-the-art instrumentation.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Nathaniel I Shank
